Now the FLOODS are coming! Essex village is evacuated and troops are put on stand by as Britain is hit by eight inches of snow and 93mph hurricane windsÂ - and Heathrow cancels 80 flights

Flights have been cancelled, towns evacuated and there is chaos on the roads as the Big Chill sweeped across Britain today, bringing eight inches of snow and 93mph hurricane-force winds. British Army soldiers are on standby as the horrific weather is set to last for three days and has already caused travel disruption and crashes in Scotland (centre) and northern parts of England (top left and right). Heathrow Airport (bottom right) has been forced to cancel 80 flights as the adverse weather reached the South East. Four British Airways flights from Gatwick Airport have also been cancelled. In Essex, the town of Jaywick (bottom left), near Clacton-on-Sea, and Colchester have been evacuated due to fears of flooding. Lincolnshire, Norfolk, Suffolk and Essex are particularly at risk from the gale force winds combining with high tides to create large waves that could carry dangerous debris including rocks. Around 30 flood warnings, calling on residents to take 'immediate action', and 55 flood alerts have been issued for England and Wales. The Met Office has said up to eight inches of snow could fall, with much of the country under a severe weather warning. High winds have caused widespread problems to roads and rail networks and thousands of properties have been left without power. And forecasters are warning of more dangerous conditions to follow, as the heavy snow is set to spread wider over tomorrow and Saturday. Mixed with continuing high winds, it could lead to thundersnow and 'blizzard-like conditions' with severe weather warnings in place.

The first inauguration is captured on film: Photograph of Abraham Lincoln becoming US President in 1861 in front of a half-finished Capitol is unveiled

The Bowdoin College Museum of Art in Brunswick acquired the photo (pictured) at an auction in October and is set to unveil it today. The image shows a crowd gathered around the Capitol to see Lincoln being sworn in on March 4 1861, just six weeks before the start of the Civil War. It is believed to have been taken by Scottish-American photographer Alexander Gardner, and is one of only three known copies. The other two are in the Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution. Lincoln's inauguration took place in front of the East Portico of the US Capitol in Washington, DC. Construction was underway to replace the building's original dome and replace it with the present-day version.

Emotional moment 10-year-old Chinese twin sisters who were separated as babies and adopted by two different families meet for the first time

Audrey Doering and Gracie Rainsberry, hugged for the first time ever Tuesday (left). They grew up in Wisconsin and Washington respectively and didn't know about each other until last month. Audrey's mother looked for her daughter's 'finding ad', a photo that gets published in Chinese newspapers when a baby is placed in an orphanage. The mother (pictured right, first from left) was shocked to see that the photo (inset) featured not one but two babies - meaning her daughter had a sibling. She later tracked down the Rainsberrys, leading to Tuesday's emotional reunion. Audrey and Gracie had spoken via FaceTime before, but had never met in person.
